items.content: In this study you will be shown a series a word pairs. Please study each pair carefully. Your memory for these items may be tested!
You have completed this section. Please click continue.

This section of the experiment is concerned with how people process words. You will be asked to view words and judge them.

The words will be presented in the middle of the screen. You should ask yourself if the word on the screen is a real word or a fake word.

If you recognize the word on the screen like COLD, please press the "z" key for real word. If the word is made-up nonsense, like WERM, please press "/" for fake word. During practice, we will give you feedback.

Please respond as quickly as you can while remaining accurate. You have three seconds to respond to every word.
You have completed the study! If you have any questions about your participation, please email nicholas.maxwell@msutexas.edu. Thank you for participating! You may now close this window.
You will now begin this section of the study. Click Continue when you are ready to begin

As you study, you will be asked to rate your ability to remember the second item in the pair if you were only shown the first at test. You will make these ratings using a 0 to 100 Scale. For  example, if you are given the pair CAT - DOG, a rating of 0 indicates that you would not remember DOG at test, while a rating of 100 indicates full certainty that you would remember the word DOG at test. When making your ratings, it is critical that you use the full range of the scale! You will be disqualified for only giving ratings of 0 or 100! After studying each pair and typing your rating, press Enter to advance to the next pair..

9.content:
How likely are you to correctly recall the second item in the pair?
Type your response on a scale from 0-100 and then press Enter.

19.title: Consent
19.content:
Informed Consent

Project Information:
Project Title: Effects of Word Properties on Judgments of Learning
Principle Investigator: Nicholas P. Maxwell
Department: Psychology
Email: nicholas.maxwell@msutexas.edu

Research Description

1. Purpose:

The goal of this study is to examine how different levels of associative relationships influence metamemory and memory.

2. Description of Study:

You will be shown word pairs presented one at a time on a computer screen. You will be asked to study each word pairs and depending on the condition to which you are randomly assigned, you may be asked to complete a judgment task involving the words. Following study, your memory for the word pairs will be tested. This experiment is expected to take approximately 45 minutes to complete.

3. Benefits:

Participants are not expected to directly benefit from participation. However, you will receive 30 minutes of research credit they can be used towards an applicable course (e.g., PSCY 1103, PSCY 2203, etc.). Additionally, participants will receive exposure to research methods in cognitive psychology.

4. Risks:

The researchers do not identify any risks beyond slight boredom due to the repetitive nature of the task. However, if participants find that they are distressed, they may discontinue their participation at any time by closing their browser window and notifying the researcher.

5. Confidentiality:

Other than the consent form, participants will not place their name on any form or document associated with this experiment. Participants will be assigned a random identification number. Any data linking participant responses to their identification number will be destroyed immediately following conclusion of this study. All findings will be aggregated across participants, such that individual responses will not be linked to individual participants.

6. Alternative Procedures:

You are free to discontinue your participation at any time. Students completing this study in exchange for course credit may instead opt to complete alternate assignments. Please check with your instructor for details, as the nature of these assignments may vary between instructors/courses.

7. Participant’s Assurance:

This project and consent form have been reviewed by the Human Subjects Review Committee at Midwestern State University. Any concerns regarding your participation in this study can be made in writing to the Office of the Provost (Hardin Administration Building; 3410 Taft Blvd., Wichita Falls, TX, 76308) or by phone (940-397-4226). Any questions regarding this study can be directed to towards Nicholas P. Maxwell (nicholas.maxwell@msutexas.edu).

Consent to Participate in Research

I understand that participation in this project is completely voluntary, and I may withdraw at any time without penalty. Unless described above, all personal information will be strictly confidential, including my name and other identifying information. All procedures will be followed as their purposes were explained to me. I received information regarding any anticipated inconveniences, risks and/or benefits regarding my participation in this study. Any new information that develops during this project will be provided to me if that information may affect my willingness to continue my participation in this study.

By clicking Continue, I give my consent to participate in this research project.
